sub_title: director/editor in chief at VPRO television

profile_positions.title: director/editor in chief at VPRO television

profile_positions.description:
Backlight, VPRO‘s weekly, 50-minute, Future Affairs- program, balances on the edge of storytelling and journalism. It focuses on our globalized world in which societies, economies and cultures seek a new equilibrium. Backlight aims to grasp the quintessence of prominent trends and developments.
The series shifts between two modes of communication: it provides in-depth analysis of new developments by leading intellectuals, visionaries and mavericks – the architects of change. At the same time, it applies daring cinematic techniques, capturing the effects these changes have on the daily lives of the real world‘s citizens. 
28 x 50'' airing on Sunday 21:00  in The Netherlands.
http://tegenlicht.vpro.nl/
http://tegenlicht.vpro.nl/backlight.html
https://www.youtube.com/user/VPROinternational
profile_positions.title: editor-in-chief VPRO series Backlight (Tegenlicht)

profile_positions.description:
Straight Through Africa

Straight Through Africa is a journalistic travel series of eight episodes (45’) for VPRO TV*, hosted by Bram Vermeulen.  
Bram Vermeulen (In Turkey, Along the Borders of Turkey), after spending five years in Turkey, returns to his post in Africa.  Familiar territory, because he already traveled intensively across the continent as a correspondent between 2001 and 2009. In the meantime, the countries he visited have changed drastically. Africa is booming, they say. Many countries are now recording growth rates Europe can only dream of. But what does that mean? And what are the consequences for the people Vermeulen met and left behind at the time? In eight episodes Bram Vermeulen travels through South Africa, Zimbabwe, Zambia and Angola and investigates the changes. He travels by train, moped and Rolls Royce, meets miners, farmers and fabulously rich oil barons businessmen and rediscovers the southern tip of the continent.
Straight Through Africa  is broadcasted primetime between September  - December , 2014 on Channel 2 of Dutch Public Broadcasting Company.
http://www.vpro.nl/buitenland/programmas/dwars-door-afrika.html
https://www.youtube.com/user/VPROinternational
profile_positions.title: Editor in Chief/Director VPRO series Straight Through Africa (Dwars door Afrika)
Editor in Chief/Director  VPRO

profile_positions.description:
Dutch journalist Natalie Righton took off in 2010 for a three year adventure as correspondent for national newspaper de Volkskrant in Afghanistan. Photographer Ton Koene accompanied her and started filming her way of working and living in the course of her last year in this war torn country. Righton and Koene take the audience on a breath taking trip through Afghanistan. They travel unembedded, dressed in traditional Afghan clothes and speak with civilians and refugees, taliban and warlords, Western military and Afghan police. What has been the result of more then 10 years of war on terror?
http://www.vpro.nl/kijk/extreem-leven.html
profile_positions.title: Editor in Chief VPRO series Extreme Living, Natalie Righton in Afghanistan

profile_positions.description:
Journalist Esmeralda van Boon and author Monique Samuel guide us through postrevolutionary Egypt. What does the freedom that the people of Egypt fought for, and so many died for, look like today? Did the lives of the Egyptians become any better? The confusing times after the fall of Mubarak still continue, the search for a new Egyptian identity is stronger then ever. The two women return to Cairo they both know very well and speak with their friends about the uncertain future.
http://www.vpro.nl/kijk/de-vrijheid-van-tahrir.html
profile_positions.title: Editor in Chief/Director VPRO series The Freedom of Tahrir (De vrijheid van Tahrir)

profile_positions.description:
Prize winning series Along the Borders of Turkey (Dick Scherpenzeelprijs 2012)
Correspondent Bram Vermeulen travels along the borders of Turkey. With collapsing Europe on one side and the unstable regimes in the Arab world on the other, the Turkish influence is growing. 
Turkey finds itself at the heart of these shifting balances of power. Big changes take place with big consequences for the people living in the region. Vermeulen searches for the true dividing lines between neighbors on both sides of the Turkish borders of Greece, Cyprus, Syria and Irak. An important quest for more understanding about both Turkish as European relationships with these troubled countries.
http://programma.vpro.nl/inturkije
profile_positions.title: Editor in Chief/Director VPRO series Along the Borders of Turkey VPRO (Langs de grenzen van Turkije)

profile_positions.description:
WHY POVERTY? is a transmedia project involving over forty public broadcasters worldwide who have committed themselves to devoting an entire week on television, radio and internet to the theme of Poverty.
http://www.whypoverty.net/nl
profile_positions.title: Projectmanager in the Netherlands of WHY POVERTY?

profile_positions.description:
Prize winning series In Turkey (Erasmus Euro Media Award 2011)
Correspondent Bram Vermeulen travels through Turkey, the country we thought we knew. A trip full of discoveries in a rapidly changing country from the Mediterranean to the snow in the far east, from the closed borders with Armenia to the open borders within the Arab countries.
Bram Vermeulen meets with  shepherds and businessmen, students , farmers and film-directors to talk about the changes that Turkey is going through. A portrait of a country that is shifting its borders in every sense of the world.  
www.vpro.nl/inturkije
http://programma.vpro.nl/inturkije/afleveringen/in-turkije.html
profile_positions.title: Editor in Chief /Director VPRO series IN TURKEY (In Turkije/VPRO)

profile_positions.description:
BEAGLE:ON THE FUTURE OF SPECIES is a 35-part tv-series.
To celebrate Charles Darwin's 200th birth year, and the 150th anniversary of his publication of "On the Origin of Species", VPRO was running a multimedia project including a 35-part tv-series called Beagle: On the future of species. Life on earth is under continual change. Is there reason to worry about the future? Can science offer us sufficient answers to some of our most compelling questions? Are we leaving behind an inhabitable world for future generations? 
http://beagle.vpro.nl/
profile_positions.title: Editor in Chief of VPRO series BEAGLE:ON THE FUTURE OF SPECIES, a 35-part tv-serie
